components.content: User guide
HTML Email Builder

With this tool, using a drag-and-drop interface and predefined blocks, you can build an HTML email template that is safe to use in email clients. The result is responsive. Using the preview mode, you can see what the email will look like on different devices. The generated MJML markup gets translated into HTML, which you can use in your emails. The project state is saved in a JSON file that contains all the settings and images that you're using in the project and can be imported back into the app. Your changes will also be automatically saved in the browser to prevent data loss.
To paste the email into Outlook, use a third-party plugin such as
Insert HTML by Designmodo
and paste the exported HTML code there.
You can add components in the
Blocks
panel. The
Layers
panel shows how the components are nested within each other. This can be useful when trying to locate a layout issue. In the
Styles
panel, you can customize the styles of any component, and in the
Attributes
panel, you can change the HTML attributes of a component, for example the alt attribute to provide alt text for images or the href attribute for links.
You can use standard keyboard shortcuts to work with the project:
• Ctrl + A or ⌘ + A to Select all
• Ctrl + Z or ⌘ + Z to Undo
• Ctrl + Shift + Z or ⌘ + Shift + Z to Redo
• Ctrl + S or ⌘ + S to Save the project file
See more about GrapesJS
See more about MJML
Images

You can provide source URLs for the images, or upload them from your drive directly. In that case, they will be scaled to a maximum resolution (600px × 400px) and embedded into the document. To keep the size of the document smaller, it is recommended to host the images somewhere else and only provide the URLs.
Double click on an image to open the
Asset Manager
. The images that are uploaded from a drive get saved in the project file automatically and will get retrieved when you load the project again from a file or from the autosave.
Columns & Tables
Use columns or tables for layout.
Columns are responsive, but the compatibility may be lacking among email clients - in that case, columns will collapse into rows on all viewport widths.
Tables aren't responsive, but they guarantee that the columns won't collapse into rows. When working with tables, it may be convenient to toggle on component borders.
